Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Basic statistical programming, elementary concepts in regression and probability.
I learned how to properly read and interpret statistics.

I had no experience with statistics before, and was honestly very afraid of the subject, but this class provided me with huge amounts of insight that I hope to apply (confidently!) in my upcoming senior essay. It was also my first time working with MINITAB, something I feel very comfortable with now.
I learned a lot about Statistics and how its used in the world.
I learned about various systems with which to analyze quantitative and qualitative data. I also learned the basic questions to consider when constructing or evaluating a statistical study.
This was a great introduction to statistics course, and I feel that I am prepared to deal with real, basic statistical problems in my field.

This course is a decent introduction into statistics at the college level, which is suitable even for students who have never taken a statistics course before. You won't learn a ton, or really any at all, computational skills, but you will gain a decent amount of statistical literacy.
I learned basic statistics, and gained an in-depth analysis of the basics of regression.
I learned the basics of statistical analysis and how to use Minitab. I also learned how to think statistically about different problems.
I developed the ability to use statistical analysis software in the context of real-world problems.

I learned a multitude of skills about what types of tests to use in statistics, how to analyze a data set, and what graphs are best for which types of data. This course also taught me a lot about using the program Minitab, which is very useful in Statistics fields.
Some knowledge of basic statistics, including regression.
I learned basic statistical theory and methods, including how to analyse such data.
I learned data analysis skills like ANOVA and regression.
I learned how to use minitab and run some statistical tests. I also learned basic concepts in statistics.
This is a very basic statistical survey, but it is a great base of skills.
I learned valuable statistical skills

This course was extremely helpful in developing the basic skills of statistics. I learned the techniques of Regression and ANOVA but more importantly, real life scenarios where I can apply these skills.
Basic understanding of statistics and data analytics.
I gained a baseline understanding of statistics and how to identify key terms.
I developed skills in data analysis, organization, and critical problem solving.
Using software to do stats.
Problem solving

I acquired basic skills of statistics through using minitab. I think I also got a lot better at realizing when I needed help and asking the right questions during office hours to maximize my time with TAs.
how to analyze different types of data
If you want to begin a journey into understanding statistics, take this course. This is a comprehensive and well taught, yet easy, introduction to statistical analysis.
This course provided us with the knowledge to perform basic statistical analysis.
General statistical knowledge with correlation to basic algebraic relationships but nothing too complex
The skills I developed throughout this course include working intuitively, analyzing information, and taking advantage of the resources Yale has to offer.

Good introduction to foundations of statistics. I think the most important skill I gained was learning how to use Minitab software to make nice looking statistical graphs. That will definitely come in handy down the line.
I like how the class started with all sections going to the same lecture and then splitting. I wish we had been assigned TAs so I had felt more inclined to reach out for help.

The biggest strength is BY FAR the recorded lectures/media library. They were crucial to my homework completion process, and I would always refer back to them, especially as a non-STEM major who usually struggles with so much information being delivered so quickly. I don't know if I would have passed the class without them, and I feel I not only passed the class, but dominate and understand the material. Prof. Reuning is an amazing and clear lecturer, so this helps us maximise the benefits from having him as an instructor.
The course is overall very good.
I really liked how the course was structured. The instructor incorporated fun review games, funny jokes, and ample opportunities to attend office hours.

This course is a solid introduction to statistics. I feel much more statistically literate after taking this course, and feel more comfortable reading studies and research papers. However, I do not feel as if I gained any real computational skills. MiniTab essentially does all of the work for you, so there isn't much that you learn outside of that. Additionally, the constant refrain that it is necessary to take more courses in the department to learn how to do things for real, or understand why things work the way that they do, was incredibly frustrating and disheartening for someone who only planned on taking intro statistics.

Strengths: The TAs are extremely helpful and active. Johnathan is a very understanding professor. The recorded lectures are a HUGE plus. 
Weaknesses: Problem sets can range from relatively difficult to surprisingly difficult.

I think the course is super well-oriented to facilitate learning. Between all of the online resources, the TAs, and Jonathan's willingness to help us in any way we needed, the whole S&DS 102 staff were amazing at what they did. Even if you missed class, it was not difficult to catch up on learning some of the material. While I do not feel like I learned everything that was taught, that was partially my fault for not putting as much work into it as I should have. But, when I needed to study or do a PSet, I had a ton of resources at my disposal. I think they could improve by providing more example problems on Canvas.

Strengths in this course are: the professor, he was so engaging in class and so informative; the TAs, they were extremely helpful in Office Hours; the Problem Sets, they were always a good level of difficulty and highly related to what we had just done in class. There were no weaknesses of this course.

It was way to easy to get an A in this class without actually learning very much. The open note homeworks and exams and the watchable lectures combined to make it possible to just skate through the semester figuring out how to do the work just when it needed to get done.

The strengths of this course is that it teaches you how to analyse statistical data in basic ways, which is very important for STEM and non-STEM majors alike. If you work hard and spend lots of time on the psets then you can easily get at least 90s on them. 

However, this course progresses very very quickly, so you really need to stay on top of the coursework and lectures. Also, the midterms are much more difficult than the psets and ask you to apply your knowledge in new ways which can be extremely challenging.
The course readily provides opportunities for students to get help and review confusing material. Overall, there arent any weaknessses in my view.
Strengths included how engaging lecture was.
Very clear, helpful instructor and tas

The course does move fast mostly because of the amount of material covered. Additional lectures maybe recorded in advanced and posted on the weekends could help in helping students who are not following the material and the pace of the course.
Awesome opportunity to watch lectures from home at your own pace...Professor makes otherwise boring material interesting.

I thought the instructor was amazing. I think that more equitably spaced office hours could help, but truly, the class was really well conducted and the PSETS were helpful in understanding the material.

Professor Reuning-Scherer went above and beyond to make everything about this course convenient. We could sit in our dorms and watch lectures that he helpfully recorded for us, and 2 out of our 3 major tests were take-home. There were also multiple TAs office hours every day, so we could get help whenever we needed it.

Strengths are the professors charisma and how interesting the subject matter is. The weakness is absolutely the computer program, MINITAB, that we had to use. It does not run natively on Macs and I had to buy a flash drive in order to be able to use any of the data we needed for the problem sets.
Very fast paced and sometimes hard to grasp because I had little background in stats.
JDRS is a very enthusiastic professor, making statistics more interesting to learn about. The class is designed to facilitate learning and is perfect for people who need a background in statistics.

strengths: recorded lectures, helpful TAs like Colin and Gena, posted detailed slides early in advance to annotate or print out or just for general reference, the examples JRS would give in class, can get minitab for free through yale so you didn't have to pay anything to take the class, multiple resources for help

weaknesses: felt like we were tested on things that weren't explicitly mentioned or explained in lectures, some of the TAs weren't helpful and once even gave me wrong advice soon before the psets were due, massive lecture size, the first 5 weeks as S&DS 100x and the last weeks of the semester splitting up into different sections was a little confusing

strengths - recorded lectures that are super clear and engaging, straightforward tests
weaknesses - more resources for psets

This course was very well-structured toward facilitating student learning, the professor and the TA's were excellent and made the class material extremely approachable, even for those of us with minimal or no stats background.

The strength of the course is that Jonathan teaches in a very understandable and engaging way. I really appreciated the fact that he recorded all of the classes and provided us with additional recorded material to review. The weakness of the class is possibly that we went through material extremely quickly, but this was acknowledged the first day of class.

Strengths = the freedom with watching lecture and taking tests online - better way for me to learn
Weak = none

JRS is hilarious, so the lectures are fun. I also think a strength is office hours. Most of the TAs were really helpful. I think the class could maybe be improved by slowing down lectures. I barely retained any information from lecture itself.
Yes, it provides very useful information to anyone that wants to better understand social science research, political polling and other things like that.
I would because I think I got a strong understanding of basic statistics and how statistics apply to fields outside of math and data analysis.
Yes I would. Its a great course.

Yes! I took this class in order to become well-versed in the language of statistics, and it did the job. The class is particularly helpful for humanities and social science majors who encounter statistical data in readings and papers.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The work load was manageable, the material was interesting and applicable, and the professor was engaging and. funny. Overall, a great course.
This is a great QR if you need one. JDRS does everything he can to make it as easy as possible.

I would recommend this course to someone with no background in statistics who is just looking for a basic introduction. However, if you are really interested in the subject matter, and are looking to get substantial skills out of the course, I would strongly recommend a higher level course.
For a basic statistics course, this course is ok. It is not amazing but sufficient for the knowledge needed.
I would absolutely recommend this course to other Yalies. The amount of information at our disposal made it great, and Jonathan's great teaching style also really helped us understand it.
Yes, especially as a relevant QR credit for non-STEM majors.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student because it was engaging, informative, and seems highly relevant to our world filled with data sets and numbers. Especially for students who are not going into STEM fields, this is a great course for background knowledge in the Statistics field.

If you want a very cursory, basic knowledge of statistics and dont want to work hard to get an A, this course is a great option. If you want to learn R, the coding language, or a lot in general, find something more interesting.
Yes, I would recommend this course to someone else, both STEM and non-STEM majors alike. It is NOT a gut and you should also find lots of friends / study buddies for the psets / other work.
Yes, I think the professor is very interesting and focuses on deeper learning.
Yes, the course gave me a great basis for further learning about statistics.
This is great for an easy walkthrough of beginnings stats. Very conveniently set up, with lots of opportunities for help and improvement.
Yeah its a really helpful class to understand statistics
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student even if they arent interested in anything stats related.
Yes if you want to be able to understand data in general articles
Yes. Awesome professor/manageable workload. No knowledge of Stats necessary.
Yes. I'm not a stem person, but the class was accessible and practical.
I woul.
Yes it is a doaable QR credit for those not savvy in math.
Yes! Perfect for non-mathematics people needing a QR. It moves quickly but is great background knowledge to have and the Professor is very enthusiastic and helpful.
I would recommend it to any student who was interested in learning the basics of statistics.
yes, pretty straight forward class

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially if they had no stats background and wanted to gain the tools to perform basic statistical analysis and a working knowledge to understand statistical analysis in academic papers/publications.
Yes! Stats is used in basically everything and this course helped me understand material I've learned previously in biology and math classes.
Yes

Yes, I would recommend this course to others because it is taught in a very accessibly manner which makes the course manageable. The information is taught with everyone's interests in mind and help is always available.
Yes if you want cold hard stats skills. Not if you are looking for something intellectually stimulating.
